elements.content:
You'll be told about other screening you can get during your pregnancy, including screening for:

  • Down Syndrome and other conditions
  • to check for twins
  • to estimate your due date.

You may be charged for some of this screening.

Screening for Down Syndrome and other conditions

elements.label: The first free antenatal blood test
elements.content:
The first test you can get is a free blood test. You can choose to test for:

  • HIV
  • syphilis
  • diabetes or your risk of developing diabetes
  • your resistance to rubella
  • your blood type and antibodies.

Your doctor or lead maternity carer can refer you for this test.

Antenatal blood tests

HIV screening

elements.label: Further screening
elements.content:
You'll be told about other screening you can get during your pregnancy, including screening for:

  • Down Syndrome and other conditions
  • to check for twins
  • to estimate your due date.

You may be charged for some of this screening.

Screening for Down Syndrome and other conditions

elements.label: This label is ignored
elements.content:
As soon as you know you're pregnant, you need to choose a lead maternity carer (LMC). Most LMCs are registered midwives, but they can also be obstetricians — doctors who specialise in pregnancy and childbirth — or family doctors who provide maternity care.

If you're eligible, you'll get free or subsidised maternity care unless you to choose a specialist as your LMC.

elements.label: Who can get free or subsidised maternity care
elements.content:
You'll get access to free or subsidised maternity care if you, or your partner by de facto relationship, marriage or civil union, is:

  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident
  • an Australian citizen or permanent resident who's lived, or intends to live, in New Zealand for 2 years or more
  • under 17 and your parent or guardian is eligible
  • a work visa holder who's eligible to be here for 2 years or more
  • an interim visa holder who was eligible just before you got the interim visa
  • a New Zealand Aid Programme student
  • a commonwealth scholarship student
  • a refugee or protected person, or in the process of applying or appealing for refugee or protection status
  • a victim of people trafficking.

elements.label: What an LMC does
elements.content:
Your LMC will:

  • provide care throughout your pregnancy
  • provide information about choices you can make, eg where to give birth
  • be with you when you give birth
  • provide care to you and your baby for 4-6 weeks after the birth
  • refer you or your baby to a specialist, if needed.

elements.label: an expandable content section with quite a long name on it

elements.content:
Postnatal depression affects some parents in the first year after having a baby.

Signs

It's normal to feel down, unsure or anxious in the first few weeks after having your baby. If these feelings last longer than a few weeks, they could be signs of postnatal depression.

Signs include:

  • crying a lot
  • feeling hopeless, alone or guilty
  • feeling angry
  • not sleeping
  • feeling that you're a bad parent
  • thoughts of harming you or your baby.

Getting help

Postnatal depression is treated with medication and therapy. Talk to your:

  • midwife or obstetrician
  • Well Child Tamariki Ora nurse
  • family doctor or practice nurse.

You can also call the depression or Plunket advice lines:

  • Depression freephone: 0800 111 757
  • Plunketline freephone: 0800 933 922

Personal information submitted to the Department of Internal Affairs (Internal Affairs)

Internal Affairs collects personal information in order to provide you with a variety of services (for example, in the provision of passports and birth certificates). You may browse and access information contained within this website without providing personal information, however, where you voluntarily provide personal information (e.g. through online forms or applications) we will keep and use that information for the purpose with which it was collected. If you want further information about Internal Affairs’ general privacy policy use the following link:

Learn more about general privacy issues and personal information related to the Internal Affairs’ services.
